title: R45111
content: President Trump signed the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 into law, which included the creation of a Joint Select Committee on Budget and Appropriations Process Reform. This committee was tasked with providing recommendations and legislative language to significantly reform the budget process. The Joint Select Committee on Budget and Appropriations Process Reform was established by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 to provide recommendations and legislative language for significant budget process reform. The committee consisted of 16 members appointed by House and Senate leaders, with co-chairs appointed jointly by the Speaker of the House and the majority leader of the Senate. The Joint Select Committee on Budget and Appropriations Process Reform was established by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018. It consisted of 16 members appointed by House and Senate leaders, with co-chairs appointed jointly by the Speaker of the House and the majority leader of the Senate. The committee included members appointed by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer. The committee terminated on December 31, 2018, with federal agencies providing technical assistance if requested. The Joint Select Committee on Budget and Appropriations Process Reform, established by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018, allowed for employees of the legislative branch to be detailed to the committee on a nonreimbursable basis. It had an authorization for use of up to $500,000 from the Senate's appropriations account for expenses, disbursed by the Secretary of the Senate. The committee was required to hold its first meeting within 30 days of enactment, with co-chairs providing an agenda at least 48 hours in advance. Meetings and a markup were held on various dates in 2018. The Joint Select Committee on Budget and Appropriations Process Reform, established by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018, held meetings and a markup on various dates in 2018. The committee was authorized to hold hearings, take testimony from witnesses, and provide recommendations and legislative language to reform the budget process. Witnesses were required to submit written testimony before appearing, and the committee had specific quorum requirements for voting, meeting, and holding hearings. The committee was required to vote on a report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations by November 30, 2018. The Joint Select Committee on Budget and Appropriations Process Reform was required to make reports and proposed legislative language publicly available before consideration. Approval by majority members from both parties was necessary, with nine members constituting a quorum for voting. Members could submit additional views for inclusion in the report if recommendations and legislative language were approved. The Bipartisan Budget Act established procedures for Senate consideration of legislative language reported by the Joint Select Committee on Budget and Appropriations Process Reform. The act required timely submission of reports and legislative language to key officials within 15 days of approval. Senate majority leader had to introduce proposed legislation the day after receiving it. No provisions were made for introducing recommendations in the House. The Bipartisan Budget Act outlined procedures for Senate consideration of legislative language from the Joint Select Committee on Budget and Appropriations Process Reform. The act did not specify procedures for House consideration, resolving differences between chambers, or handling a presidential veto message. Once recommendations were introduced in the Senate, the Budget Committee had seven session days to report the bill without revisions, or it would be automatically discharged. The Budget Committee must report the bill within seven session days, or it will be automatically discharged. The majority leader can move to consider a joint committee bill within two days, with a maximum of 10 hours for debate. A three-fifths vote is required to further limit debate. The act required a three-fifths vote for the Senate to consider recommendations of a joint select committee. All points of order against the motion to proceed were waived, and a vote had to occur by the end of the 115th Congress. If approved, the joint committee bill could be fully debated and amended under regular Senate rules. The joint select committee held public hearings on current challenges and possibilities for improvement in the budget and appropriations process in Congress. Testimony was heard from various Members of the House and Senate, including Speaker of the House Paul Ryan and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, with a focus on the role of the budget resolution and options to strengthen its impact on budgetary actions. Former Members also provided historical perspectives on enacting budget legislation. The committee held meetings to discuss reforms to the budget and appropriations process, leading to recommendations for a two-year budget cycle and other related concerns. Former Members provided historical perspectives on enacting budget legislation. The committee made recommendations for a two-year budget cycle and changes to the Senate Budget Committee's membership. They also agreed on voting rules for adopting amendments during the markup of the draft legislation. The committee's agreement required separate majorities from each party for the draft bill. The final vote was not agreed upon, with one aye and seven noes from appointees of the Speaker of the House and Senate majority leader, and seven ayes and zero noes from appointees of the House and Senate minority leaders.
